Needs investigation with the recent rule changes and progress reporting 
changes we have been doing.

John I need some consulting here...
We have set a scheduling rule on a job that as a side effect triggers another 
job with a different rule. How do I make the world a happy place?

There are no jobs involved here. It looks like a misuse of scheduling rules.
AntTargetsTab.getTargets() does this:

PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getProgressService().runInUI(context, operation,
AntUtil.getFileForLocation(expandedLocation, null));

The problem is, this code is being run from within a resource change listener. 
It doesn't make sense for code inside a resource change listener to obtain a
scheduling rule, because it is not allowed to modifying resources anyway (see
also discussion in bug 65146). Trying to get a rule in a listener generally
won't work, because the listener might be called from within the scope of a
thread that has a completely different scheduling rule. 

Essentially, this error is saving you from the deadlock that would have been
caused by this code pattern (unrelated locks being acquired consecutively within
a single dynamic scope).

Ideally, if there is any complex code inside a resource change listener it
should be factored out into a separate job--especially if it needs to modify
resources or markers.  For a quicker workaround, you can use
IWorkspace.isTreeLocked() to determine if you are within a resource change event
callback, in which case you would not get any resource scheduling rules.

As always, thanks John. Is your bug reference in comment #3 correct?

The AntTargets#getTargets() does not modify the resource in anyway but wants 
to make sure that no one else modifies that particular resource during the 
retrieval of the targets.
So my plan is to use John's trick:
if the tree is locked --> no scheduling rule as no resource can be modified
if the tree is not locked --> scheduling rule for the buildfile

verified.
DarinS, please update build notes
